author: root
title: Worlds Together Worlds Apart Chapters 9
description: Review set for Mr Diffley's World History class

list.name: Hijaz
list.definition: The western, coastal region of the Arabian Peninsula. It was the site of the holy cities of Mecca and Medina.

list.name: Mecca
list.definition: The holiest city of Islam; Muhammad's birthplace

list.name: hijra
list.definition: Muhammad's move to Medina. Start of the Islamic calendar (632 CE)

list.name: umma
list.definition: The community of all Muslims

list.name: The Quran
list.definition: The holy book of Islam

list.name: Hadith
list.definition: Traditional records of the deeds of Muhammad, and his quotations

list.name: Five Pillars of Islam
list.definition: Declaration of faith, prayer, alms, fasting, and pilgrimage

list.name: Rightly guided Caliphs
list.definition: The first four rulers of the Islamic world (632-661) after the death of Muhammad. They were chosen by the umma.

list.name: jihad
list.definition: A holy struggle or striving by a Muslim for a moral or spiritual or political goal

list.name: dar al-Islam
list.definition: An Arabic name that means the "house of Islam" and that refers to lands under Islamic rule

list.name: dar al-harb
list.definition: An Arabic name that means the "house of war" and that refers to lands under non-Islamic rule

list.name: Umayyad Caliphate
list.definition: The first hereditary dynasty of Muslim caliphs (661 to 750 CE). From their capital at Damascus, they ruled an empire that extended from Spain to India. Overthrown by the Abbasid Caliphate.

list.name: Treatment of non-Arabs in the Umayyad Caliphate
list.definition: Religious freedom, but non-Arabs had to pay a special tax but were allowed to convert to Islam. However, still mistreated non-Arabs, even converts. They were also not allowed to serve in the military.

list.name: Abbasid Caliphate
list.definition: The dynasty that came after the Umayyads. They moved the capital to Baghdad. They were more tolerant of non-Arabs and allowed them to serve in the military.

list.name: ulama
list.definition: Islamic religious scholars

list.name: Sharia Law
list.definition: Islamic law; a combination of the Quran and the Hadith.

list.name: Changing status of women in Islam
list.definition: Women had set rights now, but also had set strictures they must follow

list.name: The House of Wisdom
list.definition: A center of learning established in Baghdad in the 800s

list.name: Al-Andalus & religious diversity
list.definition: Muslim Spain; religiously diverse

list.name: Great Mosque of Cordoba
list.definition: A mosque in Spain that was converted to a Christian church when the Christians took over the city

list.name: Barmaki family
list.definition: A family of Persian descent that served the Abbasid caliphs in Baghdad
